moves.2. Bc4: I feel like a Bishops opening.
moves.2... Nf6: Allowing me to play for my favorite gambit.
moves.5. dxc3: And so begins the journey into the Boden-Kieseritsky Bishop Gambit.
moves.5... Nc6:
? Missing the threat to f7.
Alternative variation: 5... f6
moves.6... f5: !? The text move looks odd, but it prepares ...f4 to cut off the bishop and threaten the knight.
moves.7. Bf7+: The attack begins by forcing the king to walk.
moves.7... Ke7 8. Qd5: !? Adds protection to the bishop, closes on the king.
moves.8... f4: ! A good move which prevents tactics against the king - queen alignment by the bishop, like (9.Nxh7 Rxh7 10.Bg5+ !)
moves.9. O-O: ! Activates the rook and enables a possible future pin against e5.
moves.10... Kf6: Breaks the pin and attacks the hanging knight.
moves.11. h4: ! Saves the knight, takes control of g5, maintains positional control.
moves.11... d6: Activates the bishop, controls f5, adds a piece for defense.
moves.12. Ne4+: !? Forces a king walk, idea of drawing the king away from defensive forces.
moves.12... Kf5 13. Ng3+: ! Offers the knight to gain a mate. Its not forced, but it opens up possibilities. Bad of course is (13...fxg3 14.Qf3#)
moves.13... Kg4: ?! Chasing after a pawn, but ...Kf6 seems a safer alternative.
moves.14. Be6+: !? Attempting a positional swindle, which if not accepted still presents problems for the king.
moves.15... Kxh4: Forced, no other square, no blocking.
moves.16. Ne4: ! There is no escape for the king now. White enables g3+ again, this time with fatal consequences for black.
moves.17. g3+: ! No need to worry about the queens because the following moves lead to mate by pawn.
moves.17... fxg3 18. fxg3#: An unexpectedly fast win against the computer. I was happy to have a chance to try another idea in the Boden-Kiereritsky Gambit with (6.Ng5!), where before I had played (6.Qd5!?). I like the variation played in this game better.
